body: Jackson is in the same class of libraries we can't upgrade due to hadoop issues. This issue can stay open since it isn't resolved, but it is certainly not an easy issue to address.

@sascha-coenen I totally agree! 

Point 1 - We use codahale metrics everywhere in our company's applications, and it is a really nice library. In terms of druid, it would cover both the metric collection in the service, and then expose the Reporter interface which we might still end up implementing for each store (if they don't exist already). I could imagine this being a similar amount of code to a new Emitter.  It would also kind of require rethinking how metrics are actually named (i.e. MetricName + combination of dimensions). You definitely don't want to end up storing a Metric in memory for each dimension combination....

Point 4 - I definitely felt this as I was defining the mapping.  I did my best to make sure that every type is correct for the metric, but I may have made mistakes. While working on this, it occurred to me that this type information could be part of the Druid metric interface...

Point 6 - Makes sense, that's more convenient.

It seems to be a racing condition : 

```
!p10 zk bin/run-zk conf
coordinator bin/run-druid coordinator conf
!p80 overlord bin/run-druid overlord conf
```

by the time `overlord` started `Derby` is not accepting connections yet (or is not started yet) ... There should be a little `sleep` between `coordinator` and `overlord` boot ups ...

@fjy Yeah I'm using both https://github.com/implydata/distribution-docker and https://github.com/implydata/distribution ... A little modified versions though. It seems to be working fine, both the quickstart and the cluster setup. There is a last issue I'm facing https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/druid-user/lxY7fWGE03M but apart from that I'm ready for production.

I see there was some discussion of adding an artificial aggregation (as a workaround) and some uncertainty about whether it's valid for a push down to yield a "topN" query:

> Consider using "topN" Druid queries if the SQL query is of the right form. Druid's documentation claims that they are more efficient. (However, they may be approximate.)

Can we offer any words of wisdom in response to [this comment](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CALCITE-1121?focusedCommentId=15252715&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-15252715), the pending [CALCITE-1206](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CALCITE-1206), or general advice that might help this adapter to become as idiomatic as possible?

I do not believe that this actually resolves #2660, the topN algorithm already has a very good method of controlling how much work it should do at a given time.  If anything, the fact that something like this exists in groupBy is a "problem" and shouldn't be looked to as a reasonable solution.  It would be a lot better for groupBy to be reimplemented to not require such a parameter.

In the case of  `NamespacedExtractor`, `Function<String, String>` is used for lookup transformation.
I want to change that Map or Function to support transforming not only String to String but also list of String to String.

I was wondering about what the TimeAndDims Spec means and what it is used for. I was glad to see this pull request. Now that I know that TimeAndDims is to be used for Protobuf and Avro, I looked into the sources but did not see a reference to TimeAndDims in the Avro code (AvroStreamInputRowParser, AvroHadoopInputRowParser). We currently have set the parseSpec to "json" and are ingesting avro records with this setting and we don't observe any strange behaviour. So it would be great if one could add an explanation of what the rationale behind having the different parseSpec-types (TimeAndDims, json, text) is.
Furthermore, some code and doc samples feature these name tokens to be set for an element named "type" whereas sometimes the element name is "format".
https://github.com/druid-io/druid/search?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=TimeAndDims

```
# jar -tf graphite-emitter-0.9.0.jar

io/
io/druid/

```

It is just cannot be loaded. Btw the graphite-extension is part of the docker image and `druid.extensions.loadList`

I think it's a bug, because : 

```
new File(actualPath)
```

cannot read a path gotten from : 

```
getClass().getClassLoader().getResource("defaultWhiteListMap.json").getFile();
```

https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/45c413af7e4449153869eee889e1fb30e8817828/extensions-contrib/graphite-emitter/src/main/java/io/druid/emitter/graphite/WhiteListBasedConverter.java#L256

So it basically expect users to always supply custom `defaultWhiteListMap.json` : 

```
druid.emitter.graphite.eventConverter={"type":"whiteList", "namespacePrefix": "druid", "ignoreHostname":false, "ignoreServiceName":false, "mapPath": "dist/druid/extensions/graphite-emitter/defaultWhiteListMap.json"}
```
@l15k4 are you sure your user used to run druid is able to read the file ?

@b-slim yeah it's a docker container, everything runs as root. Imho it is clear that : 

```
new File("file:/root/imply-1.2.0/dist/druid/extensions/graphite-emitter/graphite-emitter-0.9.0.jar!/defaultWhiteListMap.json")
```

Cannot work ... `java.io.File` cannot read resources from jar files....
@l15k4 will take a look thanks for you concern !
@b-slim this should be ready for final review (and merge)

@b-slim thanks, it is weird that it works for others though. I'm using the implydata distribution and docker-distribution image.

I had to modify it : 

```
RUN java -classpath "/root/imply-$implyversion/dist/druid/lib/*" io.druid.cli.Main tools pull-deps --defaultVersion $druidversion -c io.druid.extensions.contrib:graphite-emitter \
    && mv extensions/graphite-emitter dist/druid/extensions \
    && rm -rf hadoop-dependencies
COPY defaultWhiteListMap.json dist/druid/extensions/graphite-emitter/
```

@gianm currently the URI puller workflow uses URI as the describing object for resources. As such there isn't currently a way to preserve an object from the `getLatestVersion` call to the actual pulling of the resource, but it could be possible to do if some common base class is used to hold the describing object, which each puller could extend.

Part of the original use case for using URI here was that the the lookups were intended to pretty much exclusively work with external systems, and URI provided a pretty standard "way to describe resources in a foreign system" that needed minimal cognitive overhead of people wanting to interface druid to that external system.

But once that URIExtractionNamespace is inside druid, the utility of using URI is greatly reduced, and it could make sense for the internal representation of the object to be a full java object rather than a serialized form in URI representation.

Such a change is a bit beyond the scope of this PR though, (assuming this reduces the extra GET calls enough to not be an issue)

@xvrl @gianm 

Some updates to this:
- Added real-valued continuous uniform/normal distributions
- Can specify mean directly now (instead of hacky cardinality / 2) and std dev for normal distributions
- Can specify exponent for Zipf distribution
- Added option to do an enumerated Zipf distribution (provide a list of values in order of descending probability)
- I replaced 'cardinality' with start/end ranges for the distributions where that makes sense
- I made the constructor for BenchmarkColumnSchema private and added some static schema creation methods for particular distribution types
@nishantmonu51 and I talked offline, he'll try a better approach that doesn't require making the balancing strategy closeable, while keeping the number of threads a dynamic config.

ok, i think this is ready and should fix the issue.

From an operational standpoint, there are a few spots where things like `LOGGER.info("starting loading lookup");` are called in various instances of the object. The lack of extra context in the logging messages makes it a bit challenging to get meaningful data from the message. Is there any way we can have them linked to _SOMETHING_ so that the log looks more like

```
starting polling lookup UNIQUE_IDENTIFIER_OF_SOME_KIND
shutting down polling lookup UNIQUE_IDENTIFIER_OF_SOME_KIND
```

Either the toString of the object, or the unique object ID given by java, or something?

Otherwise a log sequence like this:

```
starting polling lookup
starting polling lookup
shutting down polling lookup
```

Is more confusing than it is helpful.
@spektom what is performance like if you order your dimensions alphabetically? This is what 0.8.x would have done, so that'll be an apples to apples comparison.

@drcrallen S3DataSegmentPuller.getVersion does an openInputStream unnecessarily. I think that defeats the attempt to avoid a GET.
It looks like it was doing that to force-close the stream that was open inside the FileObject. I think it doesn't need to do that anymore, now that the FileObject opens the stream lazily.
